title: Secondary – Cycle 1 – Progression of Learning - English Language Arts (2010)
subject: Languages

document.title: Secondary – Cycle 1 – Progression of Learning - English Language Arts (2010)

0EFD2EC2D98F4F14BFC6BAB8EB2D308C.description: Structures, Features, Codes and Conventions of Argumentative Texts The student understands the purpose of the following and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when reading and producing spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts:

B5351B5146D948769AD64D543715B7BF.description: Required Argumentative Texts The student reads and produces the following texts:

62973D8710D84406AFD6829EB4F7484B.description: Exposition: Argumentative Texts. Argumentative texts try to convince people of a point of view about a topic or issue through a logical sequencing of ideas and/or propositions.

87E65F0B4A034675BDBE87DA7A7F4AFF.description: Reviews: Introduction that includes: the title and name of producer of the text being reviewed; an overview of the main topic, genre, critiques and issues raised, Content which includes: background on author and context; comparison with other texts in same genre; critique of producer’s decisions (e.g. particular aspects of the plot, characters, setting, conflicts, theme(s), and/or various literary techniques),Organizational structure that supports the reviewer’s opinion/critique (e.g. compare/contrast, respecting narrative chronology), Conclusion which contains a positive, negative or ambivalent recommendation and Conventions to establish credibility (e.g. informal but expert tone and diction, 1st person point of view)

887A77840A224B6392467743620AE9E1.description: Advertisements (including PSAs): Persuasive techniques such as appeals to basic needs (e.g. ‘fitting in’,‘luxury and style’, ‘doing good’; emotional appeals such as use of testimonials and sad music) and Media conventions such as camera language, layout, colour, sound (jingle, repetition, rhyme, voiceover).

767A593A7F0A4F49BAA5F84A01E2A9E0.description: Respect for production constraints that influence the content of a newspaper/magazine/show (e.g. word limit, time restrictions, readership tastes and expectations, layout)

26B4DE8606D44A1BAF58304219F17FEB.description: Persuasive language such as connotation, loaded words, modals (should, would, must), polarizing rhetoric, judging/quantifying/qualifying words

CED9626ED8904F2A8EEB3A1208D630F7.description: Figurative language (e.g. imagery, metaphor, simile, personification)

9FEF94404051472EA9CC56046FD185BA.description: Figures of speech (e.g. metonymy, euphemism, oxymoron, hyperbole and understatement)

470C602238614DC8BA6FABC2F9C9D48A.description: Humour (e.g. bathos, double-entendre, pun, parody, sarcasm)

3D1908CCD4F64ECCB9CAB9E425DC92EB.description: Structures, Features, Codes and Conventions of Persuasive Texts The student understands the purpose of the following and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when reading and producing spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts:

5C9EC5BC9C4045179A7E16C0BADC8E86.description: Advertisements, including public service announcements (PSAs), posters, book trailer

D437B147974D4779A580F344EC7C7538.description: Speeches (e.g. pitch an ad campaign, book talk)

866F2C36BCF346159DF12C620DCAD118.description: Texts dealing with personal and social concerns (i.e. Internet sites, documentary films, speeches)

6EBC2EDDD57E44918ED8429F2C56FD2E.description: Reviews (e.g. of books, television programs, films, music)

8DDAA71A2EA5494B99E99CC29C2D15A6.description: Advertisements, including public service announcements (PSAs), publicity campaigns, popular slogans, posters, book and film trailers.

4CDE8B47ECCB42F08AFDCE5470C9A1CC.description: Required Persuasive Texts The student reads and produces the following texts

5D5A6EE45ED3420BA6BEE0474D220C3B.description: Exposition: Persuasive Texts Persuasive texts try to move people to act or behave in a certain way, including selling or promoting a product or ideology

10D43980C5C74545ACB3FDA85E9A9ACC.description: Expository Texts Expository texts are constructed in deliberate ways and interpret some aspect of the world in a particular way. Whereas fictional texts may occupy a prominent place in our leisure time, persuasive and argumentative texts are central not only to leisure activities, as in reading newspapers, but also play an important role in postsecondary institutions, different professions and in the world of work in general.

C7144CC09F8E4F07A85CADF41CA7ABF4.description: Interviews:Question and answer (Q & A) structure, including short biographical introduction, open-ended and relevant questions, and follow-up questions: Rhetorical strategies to construct a relationship with the subject such as sharing short anecdotes, contextualizing, eye contact, paraphrasing, showing knowledge of subjec

E0EBA14E2F3241C6ACBB30C199A31B2B.description: Research reports : Structure that matches the information reported and expectations of a specific discipline/field of study (e.g. science, social studies):Cause/effect and chronolog and Classification and compare/contras:Visual conventions to convey information, meaning(s) and relationships among ideas such as in a timeline or mind map (e.g. key words and images, colour, lines, arrows, dimension and spacing): Features that elucidate/develop the content: paraphrasing, using examples, description, quotations, definitions Conventions that establish authority and expertise(e.g. formal register, technical/disciplinary diction/word choice, passive voice, proper referencing of sources)

892BC95C388041C78DDF87A8DAFE0723.description: News reports :Inverted pyramid structure in short breaking news story (i.e. answering W5 in descending order ofimportance):Features that give a sense of immediacy and prescience in a breaking news report: active voice, simple syntax and diction, eye-witness quotations and photo w/caption: Structure that suits the subject of a feature story (e.g. chronology in a profile/human interest story; cause/effect in an issues-based feature; parallel/convergent structure to interconnect two or more stories with the same theme): Features that give a sense of depth and context in a feature news story: background information, flashback, anecdotes, interview data, research information from both sides of the issue: Respect for the production constraints that influence content (e.g. word limit, time restrictions, copyright, ideology):Media conventions for specific effect (e.g. using camera angle and graphics to convey credibility; using on-site correspondent and hand held camera to create a sense of embeddedness)

365B00CCE6A24F62928100C41A831ABC.description: Conclusion(s) which highlight important facts or findings (e.g. via synthesis, interpretation of data, recommendations

BF6D388F5DF64389B1B61B0B3BF3F5DB.description: Evidence to support details, ideas, concepts (e.g. via a variety of primary sources such as field notes, interviews, artefacts; and, secondary sources such as facts, statistics, contextual information

3D20974855E148B6BF37B81D69D97F82.description: Information selected and synthesized to reflect the bias/stance of writer/producer

E7A45DB02FA341609624A736D524D924.description: Layout which visually cues the reader (e.g. subheadings, call-outs, paragraphs,arrows, headline, by-line, composition of photos/images related to print)

77E7C805259249878737401DAD19A88C.description: Information organized and sequenced using a structure such as chronology, classification, compare/contrast, problem/solution, cause/effect

001CBED52E2D481FAB680CFB13A16321.description: Structures, Features, Codes and Conventions of Reports The student understands the purpose of the following and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when reading and producing spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts:

260A224DAE194BBA81AFB68B630C778D.description: Research reports: on areas of student interest and/or expertise

2F8FA0EC09094AA59AC40EE25F1AC86A.description: News reports: Short breaking news stories on topics of personal and/or local interest, such as for an online newspaper or blog

163243DA9CBA47AAB2ACF970B23AA648.description: Interviews, including written and/or audio and/or video transcriptions

7665DD2BB1324014BBB368142B59A735.description: Descriptive reports delivered in small groups or to whole class (e.g. plenaries)

3B1F14FDF9ED472BB5C6539E8A71BE85.description: Interviews (e.g. in print, on radio and/or television)

4F6F026ABACF4C71814D8B36C23179D9.description: Research reports on areas of student interest and expertise (e.g. the media, environmental issues, health and well-being)

3950890D35C9480E9FCB59EAC3B6EF73.description: News reports in different media (e.g. television, radio, Internet, graphic reportage/journalism such as 9/11 Report)

A8F67508B7094ED6B17A3EE213D7609D.description: Descriptive reports (e.g. recounts of an event/eye-witness report, preliminary research findings)

0B464CCEEB8C4746AAA3717DC2D713E1.description: Required Reports The student reads and produces the following texts:

796B3A0A31674C768632F48836B031E8.description: Reports Reports describe the way things are or were, conveying information in a seemingly straightforward and objective fashion. They focus on the classification and/or synthesis of a range of natural, cultural or social phenomena in order to name, document and store it as information.

D82ED42FC30B481BBA2EA01F4FA95339.description: Rhetorical strategies to engage the intended/target audience and assure their comprehension (e.g. expert to non-expert register, demonstration, checking for understanding, analogy, referents to audience knowledge and experience)

2FFB5B35D572446EADE2DC6008980265.description: Visuals to focus reader’s attention on what is most important (e.g. headings, captions, labels, graphics, table of contents)

222C9CC030D4444FA70D006326421AC8.description: Conventions which indicate cause and effect (e.g. clear and precise diction/word choice; causal conjunctions such as because, consequently and therefore; temporal conjunctions such as first, second, when and then; transitional phrases such as for example, in other words, as a result) d.   Visuals to focus reader’s attention on what is most

7D0C43DD31ED4808B2A6DB3DAA49DF4C.description: Conclusion which reviews the salient points

A1244A3A9D87493F902481DC1CB6CC45.description: Organizational structure to break down, categorize and sequence steps logically (e.g. classification, chronology)

5824815230004FDC9AB8ACE3A6F3D7F4.description: Selection and synthesis of steps in a process

8884466CD8294EA99E01938293AA9EBA.description: Structures, Features, Codes and Conventions of Explanatory Texts The student understands the purpose of the following and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when reading and producing spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts:

D2354F44779D424DB20C1821AAB5E559.description: Explanations of a process (e.g. teaching something to peers/class, sharing expertise with others)

04CBA70BE8A948C68BF6271D2989B383.description: Explanations of a process (e.g. presentation of a lesson by teacher and/or peers)

B1CDE7F21AC746CB93724BCC6E1BC5C4.description: Required Explanatory Texts The student reads and produces the following texts:

0ED209CB9E9B464AB30252DD05B26A12.description: Explanatory Texts Explanatory texts answer the questions “why” and “how.” Describing a procedure and/or explaining social/natural phenomena, these texts allow people to share their expertise in a range of fields and form the basis of many texts from which we learn throughout our lives, such as textbooks and reference books.

F28A4A0B99EC4E5FB89AF04777D88D3A.description: Conventions of specific text types (e.g. use of gutters and panel shape/size in a comic; use of asides, soliloquy, stage directions in a play; use of stanzaic structure and enjambment in a poem)

F42275FCEB4F49FB8DADCCEC83F692DA.description: Conventions of specific literary genres (e.g. use of mythical characters in an allegory; scene gathering all the suspects in a mystery; quest plot structure in a fantasy; plot twist in a tragedy)

F1469EAD9625443DAD2465A880AEAE9C.description: Repetition and/or juxtaposition of symbols or motifs (e.g. allusion)

75B12221090748E5AE9274F28684D4BB.description: Humour (e.g. verbal irony, comic relief, caricature, hyperbole and understatement)

1EB8AF77DE0243938E0EF57BF0878061.description: Point of view (i.e. first person, second person, third person limited and/or omniscient narrator)

73E7171959B54BC2A92E11DEC4BEA058.description: Aesthetic qualities of language (e.g. alliteration, rhyme, rhythm, onomatopoeia)

288817326B9441FE897EB8951519F9FC.description: Figurative language: metaphor, simile, imagery, personification

5241E7AFF7CE414CAA51F0EA0EAA336C.description: Suspense (e.g. foreshadowing, use of action sequences, spooky music)

12BE85123B844E349944C8C6ED4224FA.description: Recurring motifs, concepts, and other patterns

FC17A5D23E134DE4928A66C62376F9AB.description: Features to structure the plot (e.g. series of dramatic monologues in a script; flashbacks throughout a televised crime serial; interchapters in novels such as Grapes of Wrath)

704CE188E53D401FA1CDE8AFF0EA93E1.description: Linear and nonlinear plotting (e.g. flashback, multi-narrative strands, meta-fiction)

B02E9C1375084F8CA8907EEED076B54E.description: Features that move the story forward (i.e. incidents, scenes, episodes, and subplots)

21532DCDDB26430D890F6B907B0E5E59.description: Basic plot structure: rising action, climax, denouement and resolution

F99FFB2F4FBE4080B9CCFF536F942761.description: Conflict and resolution of conflict (i.e. central problem around which a story is typically organized) such as man against man, man against nature, issues involving what is right or wrong

EADDA994754645ACABBF7425AB468D7D.description: Stock and/or flat characters (i.e. characters with only one or two qualities or traits, often stereotypes of individuals and/or groups)

A0EBA9B6CE4C45069FC710AB519A6461.description: Major and minor characters (e.g. protagonist, antagonist, anti-hero, foil)

10AFABFF25C54DA0BF86FFD827D971F5.description: Setting: the physical landscape and social context in which the action of story occurs (i.e. its time and place, and the descriptive details that construct the world of the story)

8655F69BF4D94253BFC022958FCE7458.description: Structures, Features, Codes and Conventions of Narrative Texts The student understands the purpose of the following and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when reading and producing spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts:

F11BAE025F9F4C16B52B6192269B5E47.description: Narratives in poetic form (e.g. lyric poetry, free verse, ballad, poetry of social commentary/conscience)

3B6FF4521A38490791525B1A93165CB3.description: Narratives in prose form:Derived from personal experiences (own or others’) such as memoir, photo story, historical recount : Fictional narratives such as short story, script for a radio play

D117073F075146DFBADF55C44FD490C7.description: Improvisations (i.e. for problem solving, experimenting with different points of view, specifically Forum Theatre and role-play)

4478E8ADD5C14253B32138AA5821C251.description: Spoken performances (e.g. poetry reading, spoken word, storytelling, dialogues)

8E61D2D4EC7F4424AC6EABB8CD67D4D0.description: Dramatizations of plays and other narrative texts (e.g. read-alouds, choral reading, scene selections)

559A443A46C04ACCA99AC8C815AE99F3.description: Personal stories (e.g. anecdotes, accounts of family life and autobiographical incidents)

ED480C859F194365BC0C7676F748AAEF.description: Classic, modern and contemporary literature: Written for children and young adolescents and reflecting the variety of texts in the literary tradition, including myths, fairy tales, legends, children’s literature, ballads and other poems

92770E756511485EB9D0FFA1F7E05E49.description: Popular mass-produced texts such as magazines, graphic novels, films and songs

05F9E30560754C4796DFBEA964486E9F.description: Young Adult Literature (YAL) in a range of genres including novels, graphic novels, memoirs and poetry

B8A24B4BA84243BBAAB02391BB78D385.description: Required Narrative Texts The student reads and produces the following texts:

2AFF321C3FB7480B9C318FF25401B58E.description: Narrative Texts Narrative texts are one of the oldest forms for recording and making sense of human experience, as well as articulating the world of the imagination.

F620C17BAAD64E76A5F28B4C58EEC991.description: Multimodal conventions (e.g. tentative language, gestures in a conference; decoupage/collage and/or personal photos in a journal)

A102E05A9A3346C39C94820164AB28FA.description: Multigenre conventions (e.g. poems in a journal; recount in a self-evaluation conference

D1B7A1610A4346A5816DE12CDC37441C.description: Genre-specific conventions (e.g. use of anecdotes, flashback and humour in a personal essay; questions, sarcasm, examples from other texts in a response; figurative language and doodles in a journal)

B91CA8D181B8482B94035EF34FDFC9C7.description: Tone and register to suit the genre and engage the intended/target audience, including self (e.g. distant and contemplative about a social issue; personal and sombre about something sad that happened; reminiscent or lamenting about a loss/memory)

3EF1EE7CE1054CE8A1231C18CEBA6933.description: Rhetorical strategies to build rapport, create a sense of intimacy and closeness, and diminish boundaries between reader and producer (e.g. use of first person (I or we), use of anecdotes, analogies, questions, and metaphors)

7A40D7A0ECFD4C4D96784E088DA2E234.description: Conclusion which shares a realization, resolution or judgment

9842D68FAB6F45FB9C7DA039F60B7DF8.description: Evidence from own experience including personal, global and/or textual examples

0E4BFAA3E68F48FD8A76C817165071EA.description: Organizational structure to prioritize, sequence and explore ideas from multiple perspectives (e.g. classification, cause/effect, compare/contrast, chronology)

C35A1DB39BFD40F2AE7C020C925E3A3A.description: Focus on ideas/experiences/qualities that are selected and synthesized

3ABC39CA9EA848339A1AE4755E41C00A.description: Structures, Features, Codes and Conventions of Reflective Texts The student understands the purpose of the following and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when reading and producing spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts:

481021DAD20B4A7B91607E41E4031E3C.description: Texts reflecting on values, experiences, ideas, opinions, state of society today (e.g. responses and interpretations of texts)

358AC307EB654F479FD502DC0E68D472.description: Written self-evaluations and reflections, including written feedback to peers

3E012C810C2B46C3AB6704ED647AAC57.description: Journals, real or fictional, such as reading logs, media logs, learning/process logs, writer’s notebook, diary

FF5B2E372CBF4F5781B74552398CB895.description: Postproduction discussions (e.g. in small groups, for peer evaluation)

98B552BAD5BC410587E376E03386F94B.description: Self-evaluation conferences (i.e. presenting contents of the Integrated Profile and peer/teacher feedback)

0FB9CBEA59904BC88EF70E1DBF495B3E.description: Class and small group discussions, including first readings/initial responses to texts (e.g. group plenaries)

0FA3330A82D2485BA85E3B3467056FB0.description: Texts reflecting on values, experiences, ideas, opinions, state of society today (e.g. personal essay, magazine commentary, op-ed piece)

BDE584E2C257497C8E678E3EC65387E2.description: Self-evaluations and reflections, including peer/teacher feedback conferences

54DB4CB144F940F188CCB16A4A185DB5.description: Journals, real or fictional (e.g. multimedia journals, writer’s notebooks and diaries)

DBC4E75CA2CC456199CA1FB339AB1BDA.description: Required Reflective Texts The student reads and produces the following texts:

CF89A2C4948048449AEDEB256E84BDA6.description: Reflective Texts Reflective texts help us to reflect, think and/or wonder about life, current events, personal experiences, as well as to reflect on our actions and evaluate what we learn.

0F2A869946E94E5386367B4BD57EF773.description: Genre-specific conventions (e.g. quotations from the text in an outline for a literary essay; proposed research resources in an action plan; selection of artefacts to present in a conference)

29E31B0C164F44FC9DBA3B5163A75950.description: Visual conventions to articulate the hierarchy and relationships among ideas/actions (e.g. webbing, arrows, colour coding, layout)

DF4882693BD6486C9B671089E5352F08.description: Conventions associated with thinking something through, such as informal/tentative language, pauses and hesitations, point form, use of capital letters and or other forms of annotation to differentiate ideas

9CEE610E2368412D92B6EE778096BB8F.description: Organization, categorization, collation and sequencing of ideas/information

2EA203002DC94C73B8DAD606144E92C0.description: List of actions to undertake or of ideas to discuss/examine (e.g. prioritize tasks, decide on a project’s hypothesis and scope, create a thesis statement)

09B4717F2CD44A39BF1D6DB1291370F8.description: Structures, Features, Codes and Conventions of Planning Texts The student understands the purpose of the following and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when reading and producing spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts:

36F3B816C1EE41A3B86B77ACA3157FC8.description: Action plans and proposals for projects (i.e. for action research and independent units of study)

692FF9616F1047A48FF33E65DE25ED02.description: Outlines and storyboards (i.e. for research, written essays and media productions)

AA3D7552E7434EB98981A3EAA60EF3A4.description: Self-monitoring texts such as rubrics, checklists, timelines

1822CE453FC44A2D87D833C7261AC6C6.description: Graphic organizers such as mind maps, clusters, lists

DE127C03EA644A399A23EFDB59FBD040.description: Notes and informal transcripts based on sources read and/or consulted, including class/instructional notes, and the results of individual and group brainstorming activities (i.e. field notes, minutes)

81E55DE38D3F4F9EA394F0F90AE296EB.description: Conferences with peers and teacher (e.g. regarding action plan, outline, getting the ‘green light’)

AC9E0C5752E04CE18CCBD96CEA0AE17D.description: Discussions in media production groups (i.e. to establish roles, make decisions, etc.)

79BDCA08FAD740DCB6DD0AE318C1BB79.description: Models of planning texts (i.e. outlines for research, storyboards, action plans, proposals)

E04297FFA12F4222AAD37AF562FC6A72.description: Self-monitoring texts such as rubrics, checklists, project instructions and timelines

E9B4E9FD535B4965847CEC63BE396E4D.description: Notes and informal transcripts based on sources read and/or consulted, including class/instructional notes, and the results of individual and group brainstorming activities

21C28F002CA94F0983E219C63638BC74.description: Required Planning Texts The student reads and produces the following texts:

7B6D0BE1FEC14252A5FFE0355CB5F0EC.description: Planning Texts Planning texts are used to plan and organize our thoughts, ideas and actions, and help us to monitor our own learning.

CA470028D5084FCE882701485876A911.description: Required Genres: Structures, Features, Codes and Conventions

A6A8EE2A60904D9AB55014677C643E5D.description: Makes generalizations (e.g. determines statistical significance; chooses relevant evidence to support thesis; summarizes or gives a précis to highlight key points)

C0E087D6D51941C8B3636FB2DAFE063D.description: Categorizes data/information (e.g. collates results of surveys; looks for patterns in data; identifies common themes in interviews)

FC76044DFCBE4DCD818944FB53E26A22.description: Secondary sources (e.g. reference texts, newspaper articles, books)

BDFBCC13C06644639CB6ECB8CE11B5B4.description: Primary sources (e.g. artefacts, interviews, autobiography, journals/diaries)

83038EDEEBF242059AA041BD88701489.description: Uses a number of research tools to gather data/information:

BF8F0E6A31274EE495D92A3001EC1682.description: Develops a system to keep track of data/information as s/he researches (e.g. notebook, bibliographic references)

2B11F4A22B5E48BCB2B91325D0CC63A5.description: Selects a research protocol depending on purpose, context and inquiry process chosen (i.e. quantitative or qualitative method)

B1D5EA2CED854240B459426BBCE192B8.description: Narrows topic/subject in order to focus research (e.g. lists pros/cons, creates sub-questions)

7295A80FAB614DD9BDD2F45111BD6C8D.description: Distinguishes between primary and secondary sources, both print and non-print

24164E8BF12941F99BDCC5F213C776A9.description: Uses action research to effect social change

DA2C2889D6F24247BB1B8EE5AB006E91.description: Uses problem solving to interpret data and information critically

A438CB77261C4B7598C8EDCB4B2A4B43.description: Reseach Process The student demonstrates control over all required aspects of the research process to produce spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts in a given context or situation.

46948F0907AB49A891C1DD1B8133EC7E.description: Uses a metalanguage to explain production decisions (e.g. explains the symbolism of the colour red and the mood that patriotic music creates in a book trailer about war)

BD94E8C502AA48F3A8D73041324D86AD.description: Uses teacher- peer- and self-evaluation as a resource to consolidate and reinvest new knowledge, understanding and information (e.g. records peer responses in own Integrated Profile for reference in subsequent production tasks)

1664296E4F1745A4B3A280ED957F2D43.description: Makes effective use of specific feedback throughout all stages of the production process, including rehearsal/dry run

669772B9FA55406E91ADC5B315B71AA0.description: Transforms the information from one mode or medium to another (e.g. prepares a slideshow that synthesizes the data from an action research project)

060AA341C102459CA319D68837E1176A.description: Manages resources in a presentation (e.g. checks that software is compatible, CDs are cued up)

593897CACB55446DB9BFA163C233B1B1.description: Uses the appropriate codes and conventions to present the text (e.g. uses a formal register when presenting a poster to the class)

22411BB610BB4EA29255208B22C5979B.description: Selects the most effective way to present the text to intended/target audience

EE6875A51F72453CBE4B2765EE7BCCA2.description: Continuity (e.g. ensures coherent visual style in a comic re: colour, character depiction; checks that formatting is consistent in a written text)

0DE04BBA95AC4BEE8D452A27D7A9BC7B.description: Clarity regarding the layout and presentation of the final draft/version of the text (e.g. arranges the placement of charts, diagrams or images)

67F28A0F7D0E4D21BEBBDDF9F610C34E.description: Surface errors in written language (i.e. spelling and usage conventions, grammar and syntax)

EAED3A2951174C2AA436FAC229A478BE.description: Use of stylistic conventions for specific effect (e.g. sound effects to create mood; use of exaggerated gory details in a crime scene description)

241DD69C145C46B283852B9B44B16B61.description: Effectiveness of technology used (e.g. rerecording narration to fill in gaps and/or for audibility in a radio spot; slowing down transitions between images in a digital photo essay so the reader can process them)

F95AE6A2D42D45BA91AF578B75B6F1DD.description: Accuracy in the use of structure, features, codes and conventions of the text, including respect for media constraints (i.e. applies text grammars correctly)

40555AB3021D415DA750FE318206B6A3.description: Coherence in light of the production context, purpose, intended/target audience and production criteria

5E479B97845645F8892C23C266BF0C24.description: Precision in the use of details and/or information

E170106B25F740EBBB3BB71D5EDB4416.description: Internal organization of the content (e.g. changes order of images in a photo essay)

A5ADD9BF92BC420FBE5611AA307CEAB3.description: Clarity and development of ideas, meaning(s)/message(s)

C65AC157FF0C4737A2A18330526C55D6.description: Evaluates draft/version critically, and makes relevant adjustments to enhance:

24C17E071E77441EBDE2952368903E91.description: Respects constraints of the media industry (e.g. length, ideology, copyright, layout)

D81107F62B5549C2AE6D3EEF9855CC65.description: Uses rhetorical strategies and different registers in context (e.g. uses an active voice to project a sense of immediacy)

7FD01ADBA68B4015BEE9F5603996DF00.description: Uses knowledge about spoken and/or written and/or media modes and genres to make production decisions that enhance the impact of the text on its intended/target audience (e.g. decides to place a dramatic photograph with a feature news story to move the audience)

DE321BC2877B4602B95D1104BDBB3E6D.description: Uses structures, features, codes and conventions of a specific text to communicate clearly and enhance meaning(s)/message(s)

69CF110EF6574914B8472EBB5B993F12.description: Uses relevant technology resources throughout the production process (e.g. uses a still or video camera in a Public Service Announcement (PSA); downloads digital images for a multimedia project)

E0BB4D3B1C94485A814D1CB33F7AEB20.description: Looks into issues of ownership, property and privacy common to the media industry (e.g. checks that copyright and/or legal permission can be obtained; reviews relevant intellectual property laws)

6088AA7739BA4414B9902F5DC814067F.description: Manages resources (e.g. makes appointments to administer surveys or conduct an interview; books AV equipment in advance)

4BCAC9642AE94E37A7C3A98410B8A169.description: Researches to locate material, resources and/or expertise

816AF973B1FF4E2D9CA0BCC62E2AD53B.description: Uses appropriate organizational devices in light of text, purpose, intended/target audience, meaning(s)/message(s) and context (e.g. outline, storyboard)

25306C6A0BD346DB86BB0AC2CA651DF1.description: Uses a range of stances derived from: Personal experience(s) and knowledge.

CF9163E1801A4037A19FBA250EAC4F73.description: Characterizes needs and expectations of intended/target audience to make some decisions regarding content: Familiar audience (e.g. provides additional details or information; sequences events or information to enhance reader’s comprehension) and Distant but known audience, conceptually appropriate for an adolescent (e.g. considers audience knowledge and/or preconceived notions of topic)

D855C9CC86C34AC285C0D8093159D967.description: Determines criteria to judge the quality of the text in light of the production context, including purpose and intended/target audience: Familiar audience (e.g. provides additional details or information; sequences events or information to enhance reader’s comprehension)

FB3E5409A628469DBF5CC3B58029BADC.description: Selects a text in light of context, including purpose, meaning(s)/message(s) and intended/target audience

5B642F155E254279A443CB00F7B9C95E.description: (Media only) Uses collaborative strategies as part of a production team (e.g. adopts different roles, shares expertise, sets and meets deadlines, accepts different points of view, reaches consensus)

037813DAB1F44B9096AC541E9903DC0E.description: Aspects of the writer’s/producer’s stance and how these influence readers (e.g. intent, ideology, values, beliefs)

19B8874BFFA247D29740251F5E40E81A.description: Level of formality of the discourse (i.e. its register)

8BCF8B9CDCB54864815B0FEF8090114C.description: How the meaning/message is represented and communicated

40242BD399A649CA9AE0668ED91AD8B1.description: How characteristics of the intended/target audience are represented such as their needs, expectations, age group, social status, etc.

90C34A5E7D5A47C4B12715D372910005.description: Purpose and context in which the text was produced that influence features such as its style, rhetorical devices, textual conventions and content (e.g. an advertisement for sports equipment in a popular sports magazine; an airline safety pamphlet; a film review on a newspaper Web site)

C6EF78FF93DD4C83A9F816F932AB00BF.description: Unique structure(s), features, codes and conventions of a specific text type. See also the Required Genres section of this document for specific structures, features, codes and conventions.

8E048E6D58614F4E972DD756D2ADEF1A.description: Examines model texts to guide production decisions, specifically:

87581BB74E23491398CBD68EBA7AA0AE.description: Production Process The student applies the stages of the production process to produce spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts in a given context or situation.

4B4419C3A48746AC919F9AFD6AC42277.description: Uses vocabulary and terminology that apply to a specific topic and/or genre (e.g. scientific terms in a feature article; literary terms proper to an Elizabethan sonnet)

81CDE2A6C1924EEEB0E717117B6DC0D2.description: Draws coherent conclusions by making inferences and generalizations

51A75284702B4C1584C730B58BED0719.description: Compares/contrasts own ideas, values and beliefs with those presented by writer/producer (e.g. notions of beauty promoted in a teen magazine; portrayal of the American South in novels written between 1920 and 1945)

0223C5C449E9485D9FD11D446014FB4E.description: Establishes interrelationships between the structure and features of the genre, the context in which the text is produced, and the impact of the text on self as reader (e.g. the use of dramatic irony in Romeo and Juliet allows Shakespeare to heighten the tragedy of their suicides, while reminding today’s reader that in the 16th century, star-crossed lovers had very few choices as to how their situation might be resolved)

E2D269E872F849E78B1D78EC4C3AA144.description: Analyzes how the text attempts to attract and hold the reader’s attention (e.g. how continuity is established in an argument; how humour, sound or music is employed to special effect in film; how structural irony or vivid details are used to create suspense in a narrative)

3C2B9326834143FBB89E116DF29A2D88.description: Explains how fact and opinion are represented by the writer/producer and to what effect

0595695506C24679975BD126A1F51CB8.description: Explains how real and imaginary are represented by the writer/producer and to what effec

3BD92E7E5FFD490B8498E23542750CC4.description: Analyzes dominant features of the text, such as its point of view, use of persuasive language, connotation and denotation, etc.

A6850EE7DFF141A6A6831794A8700825.description: Compares/contrasts with other texts that treat the same issue/topic/theme /event

22B9321EDE414A20927C34F0235934FA.description: Cites evidence from the text to substantiate own ideas, statements, questions and opinions

DB457660563946E992A245CED29E61E8.description: Selects relevant evidence to illustrate and justify own interpretation:

EED9874709C64BD2A1EAB25E192D0C88.description: Selects a mode and genre that conveys own interpretation to advantage in light of situation/context (e.g. interprets the conflict faced by a central character through a journal that includes illustrations and print)

3415AE81B725445693D924C83C8842B6.description: Organizes elements of own interpretation in order to achieve coherence and communicate clearly

9EA5713A472E4DD8B84A8530AD91BC76.description: Determines own working hypothesis, theory, controlling idea, or thesis statement

08C986ACD80A4E978134546A9954CB50.description: Interrelates aspects of his/her reading profile, the structure, features and content of the text, and its social/cultural/historical context

D1FB37B9C72B43E283572A7A4C1F73E3.description: Identifies characteristics of writer/producer and how this influences the purpose of the text, its meaning(s)/message(s) and other aspects of the context in which it is produced and read (e.g. inherent values and how these are represented; influence of a social/cultural/historical context on their sensibility and/or central argument)

DC343BC406C946F0AB6F8A06DDC25222.description: Locates evidence in the text of how the writer/producer creates a relationship between the text and its reader (e.g. identifies aspects that appeal more to women than to men in a magazine ad)

5E9EE7380D2B4D08A08AAD978327BA1D.description: Draws generalizations and conclusions based on evidence in the text (e.g. synthesizes key ideas and information)

1659AA6AC7B44698B9B8D4A94AF8090E.description: Draws inferences about the view of the world presented in the text despite its apparent objectivity (e.g. in a research report that presents only one side of the greenhouse effect)

6805E576DA564832A44A34F2F434E544.description: Demonstrates understanding of how information is interpreted and communicated in different information-based (spoken, written, media) genres:

27C0CAC7BDEC48309568CADE03E31C52.description: Demonstrates understanding of the difference between familiar open and closed written narrative texts by identifying:

1917B24DF3084F05A4437D85596EACA5.description: Keeps track of changes in own first reading/initial response as s/he works toward a more considered interpretation of the text (e.g. makes notes, highlights significant sections of text, begins a tentative outline)

35F833972E1345FDBA857E27DBE0DF79.description: Extends/supports/scaffolds first reading/initial response by examining details in the text (e.g. draws on own reading profile; uses information gained through rereading, immersion into texts and exchanges with other readers and teacher)

4E359B0AC42549B394ABB1AD8AE09465.description: Produces a coherent first reading/initial response to a text. See below for what constitutes a first reading/initial response to a text.

1595D97B13C348A8AB96B7EB0996CD1C.description: Draws on needed background knowledge and experiences related to the social and/or cultural and/or historical context in which the text was produced in order to read critically (e.g. consults other texts written at the same time)

8584B4D49C93407688B9E9416557D712.description: Uses cues conveyed by the structure, features, codes and conventions of spoken, written and media genres to determine significance in a text while listening/reading/viewing (e.g. recognizes the conventions of television news that are associated with credibility; recognizes the structural devices used in an editorial that strengthen an argument)

0B7F5FB6B92E4EAA9CDDFD2C33054327.description: Adjusts reading stance(s) and strategies to determine possible meaning(s) or message(s) in spoken, written, media, multimodal and multigenre texts

D7C247C8DB6D4E55AAD3A2AA7922DF3D.description: Considers the social function(s) of the text and the context in which it was produced, as well as his/her own reading context, to determine appropriate reading stance

A19C859AC4FE45E696D8374EC832410F.description: Reading Process: Interpreting Texts The student applies the stages of the reading process to interpret a spoken, written, media, multimodal and/or multigenre text.
